Situation1: An irate long-time customer challenges the legitimacy of the offer and demands thorough explanations.
Expectation2: Educate the public and the community about their cause.
Situation2: You are scheduled to be a guest on a live radio show to discuss your cause, and the segment starts in five minutes.
Story: The phone pressed against my ear, I listened as Mr. Jenkins, a long-time customer, unleashed his frustration. “How can you guarantee this offer isn’t just another scam?” he demanded, his voice sharp with suspicion. As a telemarketer, I was trained to handle objections, to stay calm, to explain every detail until the customer felt reassured. My script was open in front of me, but my mind kept drifting to the clock. In five minutes, I was supposed to be on air, live, as an activist—educating the public about the environmental cause I’d poured my heart into. The radio host’s number was already dialed on my cell, waiting for me to call in. My supervisor expected me to close this sale, to keep the customer happy. The community expected me to speak up, to inspire action. My heart pounded as I tried to focus on Mr. Jenkins’ questions, but my thoughts raced ahead to the radio segment. I felt torn, pulled in two directions by the weight of both roles, each demanding my full attention, each unwilling to wait.
